Giggle Magazine Article: Not Your Typical Park Experience — Depot Park Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home July 11, 2016 BDP CRA Giggle Magazine Article: Not Your Typical Park Experience BDP CRA July 11, 2016 Giggle Magazine Article: Not Your Typical Park Experience BDP CRA July 11, 2016 Not Your Typical Park Experience 32-acre, Family-Friendly Depot Park Opening in Gainesville this Summer! BY CRA PROJECT MANAGERS NATHALIE McCRATE & CINDI HARVEY Photos courtesy of Ben Tobias and City of Gainesville Alachua County parents, brace yourselves for an onslaught of carpool requests and beautiful bluebird days outdoors. In just a few months, toddlers and teenagers alike will be begging you to take them to Downtown Gainesville’s “Central Park.” Listed on the National Register of Historic Places, Depot Park is anchored by a restored, 1860s-era train station that served as Gainesville’s main railroad hub for 60 years. This rustic, railroad theme informs the aesthetic of the whole park — from a towering, weathered steel gateway feature to a football field-sized Adventure Play Area built around a custom splash pad. The $5.9 million park includes: a water’s edge promenade designed to host food truck rallies and festivals; picnic pavilions perfect for birthday parties and barbecue cookouts; and winding trails ideal for birdwatchers and nature lovers. The Adventure Play Area at Depot Park isn’t a “15-minutes-and-the-kids-are-bored-now” playground, either. With a North Florida springs-inspired splash pad — complete with water soakers, ground jets, and waterfalls — many of the play elements draw from Gainesville’s rich ecology and history. Kids can scale a brick smokestack and dangle from utility-inspired climbers that pay tribute to Gainesville’s industrial Power District. A series of domes hints at the traditional dwellings of the area’s Native American Timucuan tribe. Carvings of raccoons, butterflies, mice and other critters are hidden within the oak tree climber for children to discover. Other interactive play features include: a wheelchair-accessible choo-choo train replica; an oak tree climber; a sandpit with hidden fossils; an abandoned stormwater pipe; a rolling hill; dueling slides; and more than a dozen swings. The playground area is safely fenced in to keep children from wandering too far away, so parents can find a comfortable bench and just relax. Clean restrooms are in close proximity to the play area. A parking lot will be built on the east side of the park and more parking spots are available on Southeast 4th Street and along South Main Street. The Cade Museum for Creativity and Invention (which celebrates the invention of Gatorade and entrepreneurship) is on-track to construct a world-class facility on the west side of Depot Park by 2017. Soon, children will be able to exercise their creativity in the labs at the Cade Museum and then play at Depot Park. THINKING GREEN Depot Park marries environmental sustainability with economic development. It has taken more than two decades of partnerships and planning to convert the land from an industrial brownfield site into a flourishing, urban park. The park wraps around a large stormwater pond that collects runoff from Gainesville’s urban core and cleanses it before it flows into Sweetwater Branch Creek and Paynes Prairie. The southern half of Depot Park is a brilliant integration of manmade and natural wetlands. The historic Depot Train Station was restored using certified U.S. Green Building Council Gold LEED standards. Prominent features include original old growth heart pine, energy-efficient lighting and interactive rain barrels that capture rainwater from the roof’s copper gutters. Depot Park is also designed to make it easy for visitors to arrive using eco-friendly modes of transportation, like public transit, walking and bicycling. It’s conveniently located across the street from the Rosa Parks Downtown RTS Station, which receives buses bringing passengers from 19 different bus routes around the city. The popular Gainesville-Hawthorne rail trail feeds cyclists directly into the southern edge of the park. The newly redeveloped Depot Avenue features wide sidewalks, beautiful palm trees and bright lighting, making a nice jog from P.K. Yonge to Depot Park a fun exercise route. Want to learn more about Depot Park’s highly anticipated summer 2016 grand opening? We can’t wait to unveil this landmark destination! Please follow the Gainesville CRA on social media under #DepotPark2016 #GCRA or visit our website at Gainesvillecra.com. Email Depot Park CRA project manager Cindi Harvey at HarveyCK@cityofgainesville.org for more information. Originally published in Giggle’s April/May 2016 Issue Read Article Newer Post Depot Park earns $60,000 Capital City Bank grant for Adventure Play Area Parking & Directions Back to Top Depot Park, 200 Southeast Depot Avenue, Gainesville, FL, 32601, United States depotpark@cityofgainesville.org Depot Park Park Location: 874 SE 4th St., Gainesville, FL, 32601 Visitor Center: 100 S.E. 10th Ave., Gainesville, FL 32601, Monday-Friday, 8am-5pm Things to Do at Depot Park | Rules and Regulations | Rental Information | Directions Persons needing a special accommodation to participate in any proceeding should contact the City of Gainesville Office of Equal Opportunity at 352-334-5051 (voice) or 711 (Florida Relay Service) for TDD/TTY users. History — Depot Park Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home The History of Depot Park Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Welcome to Depot Park, the junction of past and future in downtown Gainesville, Florida. What was once contaminated earth, the residue from the site’s history as a rail yard, is now a blooming field of wildflowers and native plantings lined by decorative tracks that commemorate this former railroad transportation hub. The vision for Depot Park was to create a contemporary public greenspace to serve as Gainesville’s “Central Park”.  To be a signature city park located downtown and provide a space for public outdoor enjoyment unique to the city. How did the evolution happen? The City of Gainesville was awarded a Regional Brownfield Pilot project grant in 1997 by EPA, Region 4.  The brownfield site , located in the vicinity of the former railroad depot on Depot Avenue in downtown Gainesville, consisted of a 32-acre tract of land with several landowners and several former sources of contamination (gas stations, cement plant, other industrial operations, railroad activities, petroleum tank farms, manufactured gas plant [MGP], and potentially others).  The primary contamination source at the site was coal tar residues from the former MGP. Photo Gallery of the Journey In 2000, a remedial action plan (RAP) was developed to remediate the site and Gainesville Regional Utilities (GRU) began “The Big Dig”.  The area remediated was excavated to a depth of 50 feet and over 147,000 tons of contaminated soil was removed. Over 40 million gallons of contaminated water was treated and discharged.  Contaminated soils removed from the site were transported to an approved landfill for disposal. In addition, the city wanted ponds designed for the site to capture and treat stormwater from an 89-acre area in downtown Gainesville. The City of Gainesville Public Works Department developed a basin plan and designed a stormwater treatment system to capture the runoff from 47 acres of downtown and runoff from the remaining 42 acres re-routed from the adjacent Sweetwater Branch Creek.  The design consists of a treatment train approach where stormwater flows through a series of baffle boxes, forebays, wet detention ponds, a braided stream and wetlands. In 2012, the Gainesville Community Redevelopment Agency (CRA) rehabilitated the Historic Depot Building.  Listed on the U.S. National Register of Historic Places, the historic train station is a reminder of the important role this site played in Gainesville’s industrial history.  Following the restoration of the building, the CRA began construction of the park amenities at Depot Park.  Completed in Summer 2016, after years of planning and restoration, Depot Park features a  one of a kind Children's Play Area with a custom splash pad of tumbling waterfalls, water soakers, and ground jets. And a picturesque water’s edge promenade which hosts special events like festivals, 5K runs and performances. The City of Gainesville Parks, Recreation, and Cultural Affairs Department manages Depot Park.  The park is fully staffed and free to the public. Depot Park is wonderful amenity for the residents and visitors of Gainesville, FL.  Depot Park is a place where everyone plays! Thank You A special thank you goes to the individuals and organizations who worked tirelessly to make Depot Park a reality. Plan Your Visit: Parking, Amenities, Policies & FAQs | The Depot Skip to content Shows Plan Your Visit FAQs Private Events Premium Plan Your Visit Parking The Depot is located at 13 N 400 W, Salt Lake City, UT 84101. We recommend parking across the street or in The Gateway underground parking lots. If taking TRAX, please take the Blue Line & get off at the Arena stop. View Map Food & Drinks Enjoy a wide variety of well-known and local beer, wine, spirits, and non-alcoholic beverages. Appetizers and entrees are available for order at both bars. View Menu Amenities Enhance your concert experience with our amenities options. Upstairs suites include a designated cocktail server and some of the best views in the building. Or beat the rush with Fast Lane access, quench your thirst with a bottomless soda, or store your items with Coat Check. View Options Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs) You have questions & we have answers. Allowed & Prohibited Item Policies What am I not allowed to bring to the show? Click here to view Customer Safety information and restricted items. What is your bag policy? The following bag policy is in place: Bags up to 12” x 6” x 12” are allowed in the venue. All bags will be searched prior to entry. Bags that are not clear will be subject to additional search. Are cameras allowed? Professional cameras and/or cameras will detachable lenses are NOT allowed without a valid media pass. Personal point-and-shoot cameras or cellphones are OK. General Policies Is there a Lost and Found? If you lose an item while you are at an event, please click HERE Please allow 24 to 48 hours for the team to look for your item and respond back to you. The venue is not responsible for any lost, stolen, or damaged items. As a courtesy, we hold lost items for 30 days. Do you have coat check? The Depot offers a coat check service inside the lobby for a $5.00 service fee. We are a CASHLESS venue-- all major credit and debit cards are accepted. Can I smoke at The Depot? The Depot is a completely non-smoking venue. Smoking is only allowed in designated outdoor smoking areas. Where is my seat? Most events only offer General Admission standing and seating, which are first-come, first-serve. Please refer to the event page for seating options by event. Do I need an ID to attend an event? A valid ID is required to attend any age restricted events and to consume alcohol. Accepted forms of identification include state-issued ID or Driver’s License, valid non-expired US Government or US Military ID, or an official passport. The Depot has a very strict underage drinking policy that follows state law, and if you do not have acceptable ID that states your age at 21 or older, you will be considered the same as a minor and will not be able to purchase, consume or possess alcohol in the venue. Violators will be removed from the building without warnings and will not be eligible for a refund. What are the age restrictions? Age requirements differ depending on the event. All age requirements are listed on our online event calendar . If no age restriction is listed, the event is all ages. If the event is age-restricted a legal ID is required. Can I rent your venue for a meeting or private event? Yes, you can book our event venue for your next corporate event, private concert, social gathering, wedding, reception, fundraiser and more. For more information, please click here . Can I leave the venue and come back in? In-and-outs are not permitted at our venue. Make sure you don't leave the venue unless you don't plan on coming back! Ticketing Policies What are the box office hours? The box office is open one hour before doors on show days only. Do children need a ticket? All guests ages 3 and older need a ticket for entry. Please provide ear protection for children. I have tickets at will call. When can I pick them up? Will call tickets can only be picked up at the venue Box Office on the night of the event. Acceptable forms of identification include: a valid passport, a valid U.S. driver's license or military identification card with a date of birth and a photo, or an official U.S. state issued identification card. Please note that will call tickets will not be distributed prior to the day of the event. I have tickets at will call and I can’t make it to the show anymore. Can I transfer tickets to my friend? Tickets are not transferable. The original ticket purchaser must go back to the original point of purchase to make the change. If you are a radio contest winner, guest of someone in the band, or a VIP client, please touch base with your original point of contact and they will get in touch with us to make any changes on your behalf. I bought tickets but can’t attend the event; can I get a refund? Unless a show cancels or changes time by more than two hours, refunds are handled on a case-by-case basis. Please contact the point of purchase for inquiries. How can I get a refund for a canceled or rescheduled show? If you’re looking to obtain a refund for a show that was either canceled or rescheduled, visit www.livenation.com/refund for more information. If you purchased tickets at the box office, please email us at TheDepot@LiveNation.com . Accessibility Policies What accommodations exist for guests with disabilities? The Depot strives to make our venue and live experiences inclusive and accessible to everyone. The main entrance to The Depot is fully accessible. Please use the main elevator in the lobby to access the rest of the venue. The accessible restroom is located on the third floor and also has a lift for use. While our venue is standing-room only, we do have an ADA section for qualified patrons. We suggest you get to the venue early for the best viewing options in the ADA area. For all of our accessibility information, click here. Do you have an elevator? Yes, we do! Inscríbase en Community Forester Community Tree Adoptions Preguntas-frecuentes FAQ for CLG Tree Adoption Community Connectors Community Climate Ambassadors Irrigation Solutions Rainwater Harvesting Solutions City Water & Other Solutions Community Resources Be A Smart Ash Resources for Residents Pruning Project Information Community Greening Projects Get Involved Sign Up For Our Newsletter Volunteer with Us Learn Our Blog Ways to Give Ways to Give Donate Online Wednesday, September 10, 2025 Who We Are About Us About Us The Park People is a private 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization working with communities to plant trees and improve parks for a healthy, resilient future. We are passionate about our local parks, our city trees, and other shared community resources. We believe that healthy parks help grow healthy communities. We believe that our community forest not only makes our neighborhoods beautiful places to live, but provides critical functions to the health, well-being, and sustainability of urban life. And we believe that all Denver residents should have access to these critical urban resources. We work towards our mission by raising private funds for capital improvement projects of various sizes and through several ongoing programs: Denver Digs Trees , Community Forester , Mile High Tree Champions , TreeForce , and Park Legacy . We are Denver's oldest and primary city-wide park advocacy group and longest-standing tree organization. We have infused tens of millions of dollars into the city's public spaces, and we have planted more than 60,000 trees in Denver. Learn more about What We Do . Our History The Park People was created in 1969 by a small group of park enthusiasts who banded together to raise private funds to support Denver's extensive parks and recreation system. We are a separate entity from Denver's Department of Parks and Recreation, but have worked in close partnership with the department since our founding. In our 50+-year history, The Park People has infused many millions of dollars into Denver's parks through the restoration of existing park infrastructure, such as fountains and historic park buildings, and through new construction, such as playgrounds and recreation facilities. Our projects include sites in Denver's highest profile parks like the Washington Park Boat House, Cheesman Park Pavilion, Civic Center Esplanade, and City Park fountains. We also value the city's lesser known community treasures, such as the beloved Sundial & Plaza in Cranmer Park, the historic James Fleming House in Platt Park, and the award-winning Gates Tennis Center in Cherry Creek. And we look for high-need projects, such as playground builds in neighborhoods that lack access to recreation resources. Learn about our Capital Projects . The Park People is best known as the home of Denver Digs Trees , a beloved, city-wide tree distribution program founded in 1991. The program's roots grow from the initiative of a small group of neighbors in West Wash Park who organized around kitchen tables to bring affordable trees to plant throughout their neighborhood in the 1980's. These scrappy neighbors distributed 50 trees out of residents' garages their first year. Their initiative expanded in scope and was adopted by The Park People in response to a city-wide need for affordable trees. Denver Digs Trees has since become a cherished community tradition, known throughout the city as a provider of carefully selected tree species appropriate for our arid climate and urban environment. We are proud to provide affordable trees to residents in all of Denver's neighborhoods and place particular emphasis on distributing trees in under-canopied neighborhoods. Since 1991, Denver Digs Trees has distributed more than 60,000 trees to Denver residents. Learn more about Denver Digs Trees and our other urban forestry programs . Support for The Park People comes from individual donations, program fees, foundation and government grants, and corporate sponsorships. The Park People is managed and executed by a small staff, a dedicated Board of Trustees, and many hundreds of volunteers each year. Find out how you can Get Involved and how you can Contribute . Depot Park December 31, 2019 Happy New Year from all of us at Depot Park parkrun!! Join us in our special New Year’s Day parkrun at 10 am tomorrow. A great way to start your new year and perhaps a resolution to do a 5k every Saturday!! Set goals, achieve results and repeat. :D For the past 15 months we, as a community, have worked hard together to grow and share this wonderful weekly event with our friends, family, tourists, volunteers and all who come out on a Saturday morning to exercise. My wish for 2020 is that it continues to grow and makes its mark in Gainesville as a consistent venue for people of all ages and abilities to have the opportunity to do a free, timed 5k each weekend, make new friends and meet tourists from all over the world who frequently join us. As Event Director and founder of your parkrun, I wanted to use this platform to let you know that the new year will be bringing many changes for me personally, one of them being an amazing opportunity to pursue a new career out west. With this comes the reality that I will be leaving Depot Park parkrun, but with every intention of starting another one, should I be lucky enough to find a location as perfect as the one we have here in Gainesville. The play area in Depot Park, including the splash pad (which we call the Blue Grotto), meets ADA compliant standards as well.  Depot Park also has ADA compliant picnic tables under each of the pavilions as well as ADA compliant picnic tables in the park. There are ADA parking spots available in both lots located in the park and identified on the parking map on this page. There is one area of the park, however, where ADA accessibility is limited: The Hill .  This portion of the park was intended to be built out in a future phase of construction.  The City is still determining the future plans for that space.  In the interim, the Depot Park team is working to identify ways to temporarily resolve the limited accessibility in that area of the park so every guest in Depot Park can enjoy events and programs on this space. If you will be visiting Depot Park and would like assistance of a Park Ambassador, please contact the Depot Park Visitor Center during office hours (M-F, 8am-5pm) and we will gladly coordinate your visit. Susannah saw the park transform from a federal Superfund site to a beautiful oasis. Susannah and her family often walk to Depot Park for an afternoon to fly kites, walk around on the beautiful trails, and eat a meal at one of the food trucks. Susannah lives in the historic downtown Duckpond, which is very close to Depot Park. Nestled amidst the bustling streets of Gainesville, Florida, lies a vibrant green haven – Depot Park ( http://www.depotpark.org/information ), a 13-acre urban oasis that offers a refreshing escape from the city's energy.  This beloved park caters to a variety of interests, providing a space for relaxation, recreation, and connection with nature.  Whether you're seeking a peaceful afternoon stroll or a community event under the Florida sunshine, Depot Park has something for everyone. A Storied Past: The History of Depot Park Depot Park's story stretches back to the late 19th century when it served as a vital transportation hub.  The park's namesake, the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad Depot, once stood on the site, bustling with activity as passengers and freight arrived and departed.  As Gainesville transitioned from a railroad town to a thriving university city, the depot's role diminished.  In 1967, the city acquired the land and many years later embarked on a transformation in creating a park that would serve the needs of the growing community. A Landscape of Leisure: Unveiling the Park's Offerings Depot Park's sprawling green space offers a variety of ways to unwind and connect with nature: Tranquil Trails: Meandering walking paths weave through the park, inviting visitors to enjoy a leisurely stroll beneath the shade of towering trees. These paths are perfect for a quiet escape from the city's hustle and bustle, allowing you to reconnect with nature and immerse yourself in the park's peaceful atmosphere. Lush Lawns: Expansive stretches of green lawns provide ample space for picnicking, playing frisbee, or simply relaxing and enjoying the Florida sunshine. Whether you're seeking a solo retreat with a good book or a fun-filled afternoon with friends and family, Depot Park's lawns offer the perfect setting. A Haven for Recreation: Activities for Every Interest Beyond relaxation, Depot Park offers a variety of recreational activities to keep you entertained: Playground Paradise: A dedicated playground area provides a haven for children to unleash their energy. Swings, slides, climbing structures, and other equipment offer endless opportunities for imaginative play and physical activity. Depot Park transcends the boundaries of a traditional park, transforming into a vibrant community hub: Thriving Events Calendar: Throughout the year, Depot Park hosts a variety of events that cater to diverse interests. From farmers markets overflowing with fresh produce to lively music festivals and cultural celebrations, the park offers a platform for community gathering and shared experiences. Check the park's website for upcoming events. ( http://www.depotpark.org/information ) A Green Gateway: Exploring Beyond Depot Park Depot Park's convenient location allows you to extend your exploration beyond its borders: Paynes Prairie Preserve State Park: A short drive away lies Paynes Prairie Preserve State Park, a sprawling natural wonderland offering a glimpse of Florida's pre-settlement landscape. Hike through longleaf pine savannas, spot a variety of wildlife including bison and alligators, and immerse yourself in the beauty of this unique ecosystem. Downtown Delights: Depot Park sits at the heart of Gainesville's dynamic downtown district. Explore the area's vibrant shops, sample delectable cuisine at local restaurants, or catch a live performance at a nearby music venue. A Park for All Seasons: Year-Round Activities at Depot Park Depot Park's appeal extends throughout the year, offering unique experiences depending on the season: Springtime Splendor: Spring paints the park in vibrant colors as flowers bloom and trees awaken from their winter slumber. Enjoy a picnic beneath the blossoming trees or participate in a community egg hunt during Easter celebrations. Autumnal Hues: Fall transforms the park with a breathtaking display of changing foliage. Walk along the trails and soak in the vibrant autumn colors, or participate in a fall festival celebrating the season's bounty. Winter Wonderland (Florida Style): While Florida winters are mild, the cooler temperatures offer a welcome respite from the summer heat. Enjoy a brisk walk through the park or participate in a holiday-themed event like a caroling competition or a tree lighting ceremony. Planning Your Visit to Depot Park: Location and Accessibility: Depot Park is conveniently located at 874 SE 4th St, Gainesville, FL 32601. The park is easily accessible by car, bike, or even on foot if you're staying nearby. Ample parking is available around the park's perimeter. Things to Bring: Pack sunscreen, a hat, and comfortable shoes if you plan to spend extended time outdoors. Bring a picnic basket and blanket if you're planning a picnic lunch. Water is essential to stay hydrated, especially during the warmer months. Dog-Friendly Fun: Depot Park welcomes leashed and well-behaved dogs. Designated areas within the park allow your furry friend to run and play freely. Be sure to clean up after your pet to maintain a clean and pleasant environment for everyone. Supporting the Park: Depot Park thrives thanks to the dedication and support of the community. Consider volunteering your time to help maintain the park or donating to support its ongoing programs and events. Depot Park: A Testament to Urban Design Depot Park serves as a testament to the power of well-designed urban green spaces.  It provides a vital oasis within the city limits, offering a place for recreation, relaxation, and community gatherings.  Whether you're a local resident seeking a break from the daily grind or a visitor exploring Gainesville's charm, Depot Park offers a unique and enriching experience for all.  So, on your next trip to Gainesville, be sure to add Depot Park to your itinerary and discover the magic of this vibrant urban oasis. Interested in the “Big Dig” and how Depot Park was constructed? How about a brief history of Gainesville as told through the Children’s Play Area? Just want to schedule a field trip to play in the Children’s Play Area? By completing this Field Trip & Tour Request form, Depot Park staff are able to better prepare, keep you apprised of scheduled maintenance that may conflict, and ensure your visit is as smooth as possible. Here are the details: This form is a request only and requests are not guaranteed. Depot Park Manager reserves the right to refuse requests. Use of electricity, DJs, or amplified sound is prohibited without prior approval. Confetti, glitter, bounce houses, large inflatables, and water balloons are prohibited. The Children’s Play  Area and Blue Grotto Splash Pad are designed for children ages 2-12, children must be accompanied by an adult at all times. Food is not allowed inside the Children’s Play  Area or Blue Grotto Splash Pad. Absolutely no staking in Depot Park. The park is a brownfield site and the ground cannot be penetrated. In lieu of staking,  sandbags,  bricks,  or water jugs are often used. Requests should be submitted at least two weeks in advance. Buses may unload from the ADA lot at 201 SE Depot Ave or the little lot at 874 SE 4th Street. All buses must park in the Overflow Parking lot, parking on the grass or across multiple spaces in the little lot is prohibited. We look forward to making your next visit to Depot Park an educational experience! Rules and FAQs — Depot Park Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home Rentals Rentals Rental Availability Vendor Application Field Trips & Tour Requests Cancellations Cade Learn History News Sponsors About Depot Park Depot Gallery Chat Contact Us Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Home Visit Things to Do Events Calendar Directions & Parking Map of Depot Park Rules and FAQs Accessibility Weather Rules and FAQs Park Hours Children’s play area: 7am to Sunset Conservation area (the south end of the park): 7am to Sunset Lit areas (most of the north side of the park): 7am to 11:30 p.m. NO TRESPASSING AFTER HOURS Office Hours Monday - Friday, 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. Rules Absolutely no staking in Depot Park. The park is a brownfield site and the ground cannot be penetrated. In lieu of staking, sand bags, bricks, or water jugs are often used. Adults of drinking age may drink alcoholic beverages outside within the Sip & Stroll Areas between 8 a.m. and midnight daily. Please note, glass containers are always prohibited. Open containers are not allowed in public parking lots or garages, even if they are in the Sip & Stroll Areas. S moking is prohibited. Camping or open fires are not allowed at any time. Personal grills are not allowed at Depot Park. Grills are provided at the pavilions and are available for use when the pavilions are not being rented. Activities or events requiring open flames (such as candles - excluding birthday cake candles in a cake) are not permitted in Depot Park unless approved by the Depot Park Manager at least 72 hours in advance. Amplified sound (DJ, bluetooth speakers, etc.) is not permitted in Depot Park unless approved by the Depot Park Manager at least 72 hours in advance. Pets must remain on a physical leash. Do not leave property unattended in the park. Frequently Asked Questions Q: HOW MUCH IS THE ENTRANCE FEE? A: There is no charge! Depot Park is a division of the City of Gainesville Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Department and therefore is a free city park. There are charges for renting spaces , and for some specialty classes that are offered from time to time in the park, such as yoga, or swing dancing lessons. Q: WHAT ARE THE HOURS OF THE SPLASH PAD? A: The Blue Grotto Splash Pad is located inside the Children's Play Area, which hours are 7am to sunset. The Splash Pad operates year round as long as the temperature outside is above 70 degrees and there isn't lighting within 10 miles of the park. Q: CAN I BRING ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES TO DEPOT PARK? A: Alcohol is not allowed in the park. However, you are allowed to purchase beer and wine in the Depot Building - from the Boxcar Beer & Wine Garden and Pop-a-Top General Store - and consume on their patio. Q: HOW LONG ARE THE TRAILS? A: The outer most trail is a picturesque 0.8-mile loop. Our trail connects to the Gainesville-Hawthorne Rail to Trail. The zero mile marker for the trail is at the intersection of paths near the Pop-a-Top General Store. Q: DO I NEED TO RESERVE A PICNIC TABLE? A: Individual picnic tables that are located throughout the park are available on a first come, first served basis to park users. There are currently 10, four-seater tables throughout the park. Q: CAN I FISH AT DEPOT PARK? A: Fishing is NOT allowed in Depot Park. The ponds are filled with runoff from Downtown Gainesville and are lined with a plastic liner which can easily be damaged by hooks. Q: IS THERE Wi-Fi IN DEPOT PARK? A: Not yet! It's on our wish list. Q: ARE THERE ELECTRICAL OUTLETS AVAILABLE FOR USE? A: Use of electricity in Depot Park has to be approved and coordinated with Depot Park Manager prior to using it. Q: ARE THERE ANY GRILLS AVAILABLE AT THE PARK, OR CAN I BRING MY OWN? A: There are two grills located in both Pavilion A and B. Although, these are only available if the pavilions are not rented, click here to check pavilion availability . Depot Park does not provide a place to dispose of your charcoal, so whatever you bring in, you must also take out. Personal grills are not allowed to be carried into the park. Q: CAN I HIRE A DJ OR BRING SPEAKERS? A: You are not able to have amplified sound without getting special permission from Depot Park Manager prior to your event. Q: CAN I BRING A SHADE TENT OR SHADE UMBRELLA? A: Yes. However, nothing can be staked into the ground because Depot Park is a brownfield site. Please plan to secure your items with weights, sand bags, water containers or bricks. Q: CAN I DECORATE THE PAVILIONS FOR MY EVENT? A: Decorate as much as you would like with festive garland and such, but only attach things by tape to avoid damaging the wood. Glitter and confetti are not permitted in Depot Park. Q: CAN I RENT A BOUNCE HOUSE, OR INFLATABLE TO BE SET UP AT THE PARK? A: No. Large inflatables, such as a bounce house, are not permitted in Depot Park. Q: HOW DO I GO ABOUT HOLDING AN EVENT AT DEPOT PARK? A: To rent a space in Depot Park, click here . To rent a space in the Historic Depot Building, click here . And to rent a space inside the Cade Museum, click here . Q: CAN I GET MARRIED IN DEPOT PARK? A: Yes! The West Overlook is an ideal location in the park to get married. The Pavilions or the Historic Depot Building are great locations for receptions. To rent the West Overlook, the Pavilions, or another space in the park, click here. For rental information on the Depot Event Space, please visit thedepotstation.com or contact thetopsecretevents@gmail.com . Q: WHEN WOULD I NEED TO ACQUIRE A PERMIT? A: You will need to apply for a permit if you are charging admission; selling goods or food; impacting traffic in any way; putting up a tent larger than 10'x10'; playing amplified music; or holding an event with over 50 people. Contact us for for more information. Q: CAN I SELL FOOD OR OTHER PRODUCTS IN THE PARK A: Selling food, drinks, merchandise or services in the park requires special permission and rental of the space. Contact us for for more information. Q: ARE PETS ALLOWED IN DEPOT PARK? A: We love pets. For their safety, pets must remain on a physical leash. There are no off-leash areas. No pets except service animals are allowed in the Children’s Play Area. Q: WHAT IS THE CANCELLATION POLICY FOR PAVILION RENTALS? A: Cancellations must be submitted to the Depot Park Office 72-hours prior to the rental for a full refund of rental fees and deposits. Processing fees are not refundable. If a ‘Rain Out’ is declared by Depot Park Management, and the rented pavilion was not used for at least 2 hours, a request to reschedule may be made at no charge. If the preference is not to reschedule, a refund may be requested for the full rental fee and deposit. Processing fees are not refundable. Q: WHAT IS THE CANCELLATION POLICY FOR SPECIAL EVENTS? A: All cancellations must be emailed to the Depot Park Office at DepotPark@CityOfGainesville.org and confirm receipt. 30 days or more prior notice of cancellation will receive a full refund of rental fees and full deposit Between 15 and 29 days prior notice of cancellation will receive 50% refund of rental fees and full deposit Less than 14 days’ prior notice of cancellation will receive NO refund of rental fees or deposit ADDITIONAL REGULATIONS, LAWS AND ORDINANCES APPLY CITY OF GAINESVILLE CODE OF ORDINANCES APPLY CHAPTER 15-6 NOISE ORDINANCE CHAPTER 18 at WWW.GAINESVILLEFL.GOV If you have any questions or concerns, please contact us . Update 4/23: The Depot Park Splash Pad is Open The splash pad is on 7 days a week, 365 days as year as long as the temperature is above 70 degrees. We do our best to open the play area and splash pad every morning, as close to 7AM as possible. Please be patient with staff. The play area and splash pad close at sunset daily. As a reminder, in order to keep the play area safe and the water clean, food and pets are not allowed in the play area. As a reminder, for your safety as well as staff safety, the play area and splash pad close for 30 minutes when there is lightning within 10 miles of the park. Check our Weather page for the latest alerts. We also have a newly installed lightning detection device. If you hear a 15 second siren, please seek shelter. The all clear alert is 3 short horn blasts, at that time play may resume. Park Hours: Children’s play area: 7 am to Sunset Conservation area: 7 am to Sunset Restrooms: 7 am to 9:00 pm Lit areas in the park: 7 am to 11:30 pm We do our best to open as close to 7 am as possible.
